title: The Dominators
writers: Norman Ashby (a pseudonym for Mervyn Haisman, Henry Lincoln)
dialogue_triumphs: The Doctor explains his plan to a baffled Jamie: 'An unintelligent enemy is far less dangerous than an intelligent one, Jamie. Just act stupid. Do you think you can manage that?'
goofs: Episode three has no 'episode three' caption.
The rubble over a hatch in episode four vanishes.
Toba [exaggerating?] says that the Dominators are the 'masters of the Ten Galaxies'; Rago says that they control an entire galaxy.
The zip at the back of Zoe's skirt causes her problems on numerous occasions, being open in episodes two, three and five.
There's a whacking great close-up of Troughton's location double in episode five.

continuity_notes.name: Dulcians
continuity_notes.description: The inhabitants of Dulkis, with a dual cardiovascular system similar to Time Lords. They are unaware of extraterrestrial life.
continuity_notes.current_status: Peaceful civilization threatened by the Dominators

continuity_notes.name: Dominators
continuity_notes.description: Alien invaders searching for slave labor, capable of interstellar travel.

continuity_notes.name: Sonic Screwdriver
continuity_notes.description: The Doctor's multi-purpose tool, used as a cutting device in this story.

technobabble: The Dominators' ship stores radioactive particles and converts them into fuel.
roots: Aesop's fables (the boy who cried wolf)
links: The Doctor states that he is a little tired 'projecting all those mental images', referencing 'The Evil of the Daleks' repeat that bridged the gap between the seasons.
Zoe mentions both the Daleks and the Cybermen ('The Wheel in Space'), hoping that neither will be present on Dulkis.

locations.name: Dulkis
locations.description: Planet with a peaceful civilization, featuring an island used for atomic research and testing.

untold_adventures: The Doctor has been to Dulkis before. He remembers the Dulcians as a very advanced, gentle people, and was reluctant to leave.
additional_notes: The episode deals with 60s concerns like unilateralism, the hippy movement, and the decadence of the bourgeoisie, handled with reactionary disdain via the unavoidable Doctor Who motif of alien invasion.
bottom_line: A study in sadism, 'The Dominators' is also very dull.
